I _have_ tried this without the -jar option, but get a main method not
found error.

I think I need to look at the classpaths again, as I have just got it
working OK on a unix machine after eventually sorting out the setenv
property.

I have also read the documenation on the installtion of JUnit, and
really didn't find them to be very useful. In fact, I was quite
disappointed at the lack of detail it contained.

Hmmm... 'Extension of JUnit using Adapter and Observer design
patterns' coursework due at end of next week  :(

Marc


--- In junit@y..., "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> Marc:
> 
> You use the -jar option, but you specify no .jar. This cannot work.
The 
> error message is telling you, "I can't find 
> junit.swingui.TestRunner.zip!" Of course not. There isn't one.
> 
> Please read the documentation that accompanies JUnit or, if
junit.jar is 
> already on your system CLASSPATH, simply do not use the -jar switch.
> 
> Further, read up on the -jar switch in your local JDK documentation
so 
> you can better understand what it does.
> 
> Thanks,
> JBR.
>
